title: Eight Canadian destinations to be thankful for
text:
Eight Canadian destinations to be thankful for: From Alberta’s Rockies to the ‘Big Sky’ of the Prairies Jim Byers, Postmedia News Moraine Lake is a key stop for anyone driving through Alberta's Rocky Mountains. The lighthouse at Lobster Cove in Newfoundland is a great place for a short hike. The drive along the north and eastern shore of Lake Superior is a vastly under-rated Canadian experience. The gentle waters on the Sunshine Coast of B.C. are perfect for boaters. Saskatoon is very much a city on the rise, with great dining options and fine hotels. Les Iles de la Madeleine, or the Magdalen Islands, are a truly magical part of Quebec. If you like long mountain roads with hardly another car in sight, the Yukon is for you. The Cabot Trail in Cape Breton is one of the most scenic areas of Canada. Moraine Lake is a key stop for anyone driving through Alberta's Rocky Mountains. Jim Byers / Postmedia News Brews, biking and more in Portneuf: Quebec’s Hôtel Roquemont is a sociable country lodge for all seasons 
I have been privileged to live in what I think is the greatest country in the world and have been lucky enough to see some pretty remarkable parts of a country that many Canadian-born travellers have never seen. In light of Thanksgiving celebrations this weekend, here are some places I think we should all be thankful for. 
ANYWHERE IN NEWFOUNDLAND AND LABRADOR 
With only a few exceptions, every person I have ever met from Newfoundland and Labrador has offered to give me the parka off their back. These people have had a tough life. Yet they’re generous and upbeat as all get out. They also don’t take well to folks who register too high on the uppity meter. You can’t beat St. John’s for its harbour setting and colourful walkways out along the Battery. Gros Morne is truly one of Canada’s best national parks, with tremendous hiking and an iconic boat trip up Western Brook Pond. 
NORTH OF LAKE SUPERIOR, ONTARIO 
The drive from Thunder Bay Sault Ste. Marie passes truly magnificent scenery and long lake views with hardly a soul around. Hop on a boat in the village of Rockport and take a tour out past the many islands that dot this part of Lake Superior. Take in the Winnie the Pooh park and display in White River and be sure to pay your respects to the giant Wawa Goose . The Lake Superior trip would be a perfect drive if they only had more places to pull over for photos and more Tim Hortons. 
ANYWHERE ON THE COAST OF BRITISH COLUMBIA 
I love Tofino as much as the next person who loves long walks on the beach and surfing and whale watching. I also love the Sunshine Coast , which might be the most underrated part of the province with its quiet, pristine bays and wonderful hiking and kayaking opportunities. Another nice spot is Sooke , just west of Victoria on Vancouver Island. 
THE PRAIRIES 
You might be surprised by the sophistication of Saskatoon, which is home to the truly excellent Ayden Kitchen and Bar restaurant and the super-fun theatre group Shakespeare on the Saskatchewan . Winnipeg is also a city on the rise, with a new hockey arena and a growing number of folks flocking to downtown condos and apartments. The Canadian Museum for Human Rights is a beauty. 
ILES DE LA MADELEINE, QUEBEC 
The Magdalen Islands have beaches that stretch on approximately forever. There also are surprisingly steep hills, often plunging straight down to the Gulf of St. Lawrence. I loved my short visits to La Butte Ronde and Havre Sur Mer , both fine B&Bs. 
YUKON 
I have not made it to Dawson City, but I spent a week here a few years back, setting up shop in the village of Haines Junction and exploring Kluane National Park . I saw more moose and bears along the side of the road than I saw cars in a four-hour drive and I got to listen to the sound of the ice cracking at lovely Kathleen Lake. I also fell in love with the adventurous spirit of the people of Whitehorse. 
CAPE BRETON, NOVA SCOTIA 
The Cabot Trail truly is one of the world’s great drives: a swooping, swirling ribbon of road clinging to the side of steep cliffs overlooking the sea. South of Mabou you will find a pretty road that leads to a provincial park with a great beach and lovely views of the coast and hills. I also love the powerful views when you venture off the north end of the trail along White Point Road. Look for live music at the Red Shoe Pub in Mabou and awesome golf at both Cabot Links and the new Cabot Cliffs . 
THE ALBERTA ROCKIES 
The Icefields Parkway between Jasper and Banff might be the most majestic drive on the planet, with towering spires of ancient rock and clouds swirling in the blue western sky. Try a comparison gondola experience by riding to the tops of the mountains in Jasper, Lake Louise and Banff. Better yet, get off the road at a pull-out spot and inspect tumbling waterfalls and beautiful canyons along the way, including the sublime Athabasca Falls.
